questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and fever. After a thorough examination, the attending physician decides to perform a lumbar puncture to rule out meningitis. During the procedure, as the needle is advanced, it pierces several anatomical structures before entering the lumbar cistern. Which of the following structures is pierced immediately before entering the lumbar cistern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arachnoid mater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a lumbar puncture, the arachnoid mater is the final structure pierced before the needle enters the lumbar cistern, which contains cerebrospinal fluid.
  • ➤ arachnoid mater

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with history of vision loss. On investigation optic chiasma was found compressed due to an aneurysm. Which artery is most commonly involved in such presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anterior communicating artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Compression of the optic chiasma , leading to bitemporal hemianopia, is most commonly caused by an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery .
  • ➤ optic chiasma
  • ➤ anterior communicating artery

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with sudden onset of violent, involuntary throwing movements of his right arm and leg. These movements are continuous and have significantly impaired his daily activities. His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Imaging studies reveal a lesion in the brain. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subtalamic Nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemiballismus is caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus , resulting in violent, involuntary flinging movements on the opposite side of the body.
  • ➤ Hemiballismus
  • ➤ subthalamic nucleus

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the clinic with difficulty in speech production. She is able to understand language but struggles to form coherent sentences. Neurological examination and imaging studies reveal a lesion affecting a specific area of the brain. Which of the following areas is most likely involved in her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior frontal gyrus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Difficulty in speech production with preserved comprehension is characteristic of Broca’s aphasia , caused by a lesion in Broca’s area , located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere.
  • ➤ Broca’s aphasia
  • ➤ Broca’s area
  • ➤ inferior frontal gyrus

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fornix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fornix is a white matter tract of the limbic system, responsible for connecting the hippocampus to other brain regions, and is located beneath the corpus callosum in a mid-sagittal view of the brain.
  • ➤ fornix

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesions in the thalamus can cause contralateral sensory deficits and dysaesthesia, including burning and shooting pain, due to its role as a sensory relay center. In this coronal brain section, the thalamus is labeled as B .
  • ➤ thalamus
  • ➤ B

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibers from the mammillary body terminate in the anterior nucleus of the thalamus , a key component of the Papez circuit for memory and emotional processing.
  • ➤ mammillary body
  • ➤ anterior nucleus of the thalamus

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given red circled structure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem and passes through the circled structure in the given image.

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

options.label: D
options.text: Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corpus callosum , particularly its anterior portions (rostrum and genu), is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery and the anterior communicating artery .
  • ➤ corpus callosum
  • ➤ anterior cerebral artery
  • ➤ anterior communicating artery

questions.text: Which structure is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Risorius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial colliculus is formed by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) looping around the abducens nucleus (cranial nerve VI) . Damage to this region primarily affects the facial nerve, leading to paralysis of facial muscles, including the risorius .
  • ➤ facial colliculus
  • ➤ facial nerve (cranial nerve VII)
  • ➤ abducens nucleus (cranial nerve VI)
  • ➤ risorius

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hippocampus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fornix originates from the hippocampus , forming a vital connection within the limbic system and playing a crucial role in memory and emotion.
  • ➤ fornix
  • ➤ hippocampus

questions.text: Which skull foramina is formed by 3 bones?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Foramen lacerum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The foramen lacerum is the only skull foramen formed by three bones: the sphenoid , temporal , and occipital bones .
  • ➤ foramen lacerum
  • ➤ sphenoid
  • ➤ temporal
  • ➤ occipital bones

questions.text: Which of the following marked sites does SARS-COVID 19 spread to the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SARS-COVID-19 spreads to the brain via the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone at site A , utilizing the olfactory nerve pathway to enter the central nervous system.
  • ➤ cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ olfactory nerve pathway

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of swallowing and speech difficulty caused by occipitotemporal fractures, the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is most likely involved. Testing the soft palate and pharyngeal region (marked as 2 ) is critical for confirming the involvement.
  • ➤ vagus nerve (cranial nerve X)
  • ➤ soft palate and pharyngeal region
  • ➤ 2

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked muscle arise?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Red nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial rectus muscle is supplied by the third cranial nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain, near the red nucleus .
  • ➤ red nucleus

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is unable to shrug/ elevate the shoulder & he is having difficulty in turning his head. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spinal Accessory nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Injury to this nerve leads to an inability to shrug the shoulder and difficulty turning the head.
  • ➤ spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI)

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling below the ear & complained of pain in the lobule of the ear. He is having difficulty in eating food. What nerve is most likely to be damaged?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Greater Auricular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greater auricular nerve is the primary sensory nerve supplying the skin over the parotid gland, the angle of the mandible, and the ear lobule. Damage or irritation to this nerve causes pain and swelling in these regions.
  • ➤ greater auricular nerve

questions.text: A man suffered an injury on head and after this the blood collected around the eyes. Which of the following layer is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Loose areolar layer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The loose areolar layer of the scalp is responsible for the spread of blood to the periorbital region following head injuries, resulting in a "black eye" or "raccoon eye." This layer's loose attachment and lack of anterior bony attachment make it a key site for blood accumulation.
  • ➤ loose areolar layer

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a concern about a "visible vein" in his right shoulder area. He reports that the vein becomes more pronounced during exercise or when lifting heavy objects. There is no associated pain, redness, or swelling. He denies any history of trauma to the area. On inspection of the right shoulder area reveals a prominent, non-pulsatile, linear structure running along the deltopectoral groove is seen. Which of the following structure is seen in this area
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cephalic vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cephalic vein is a prominent superficial vein that runs along the deltopectoral groove and can become more visible during exercise or heavy lifting due to increased venous return.
  • ➤ cephalic vein

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the trochlear nerve?

options.label: B
options.text: Supplies the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle

options.label: C
options.text: Only cranial nerve that arises from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem

options.label: D
options.text: Enters orbit through the superior orbital fissure outside the annulus of zinn

questions.correct_answer: B. Supplies the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Supplies the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is the only cranial nerve to arise from the dorsal brainstem and decussate to supply the contralateral superior oblique muscle. It has the longest intracranial course and enters the orbit outside the annulus of Zinn.
  • ➤ trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patella is the largest sesamoid bone in the human body. Sesamoid bones are found within tendons near joints and serve to protect the joint and enhance muscle function.
  • ➤ patella
  • ➤ sesamoid bone

questions.text: Where is the growth plate of cartilage in a long bone located?

options.label: B
options.text: Between the diaphysis and the epiphysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Between the diaphysis and the epiphysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Between the diaphysis and the epiphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis and is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones through endochondral ossification.
  • ➤ epiphyseal plate
  • ➤ diaphysis
  • ➤ epiphysis

questions.text: A 21 years old patient Suyash came to OPD with history of fall on hand. Now he is having pain at hand region. X ray of patient is given. Which of the following joint has been shown in his X ray ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid joint.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wrist joint (radiocarpal joint) is an ellipsoid joint that allows movements such as flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction but limits rotation.
  • ➤ wrist joint (radiocarpal joint)
  • ➤ ellipsoid joint

questions.text: What is the typical fiber arrangement of lumbrical muscles in the hand?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - bipennate

options.label: B
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – biipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

options.label: C
options.text: 1 st & 3 rd lumbricals – biipennate, 2 nd & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

options.label: D
options.text: 2 nd & 3 rd lumbricals – biipennate, 1 st & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - bipennate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1st& 2ndlumbricals – Unipennate, 3rd& 4thlumbricals – bipennate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lumbricals of the hand have the following fiber arrangement:
  • ➤ lumbricals
  • ➤ 1st and 2nd lumbricals : Unipennate. 3rd and 4th lumbricals : Bipennate.
  • ➤ 1st and 2nd lumbricals : Unipennate.
  • ➤ 1st and 2nd lumbricals
  • ➤ 3rd and 4th lumbricals : Bipennate.
  • ➤ 3rd and 4th lumbricals

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, injury to the anterior interosseous nerve (branch of the median nerve) can result in an inability to flex the thumb due to its innervation of the flexor pollicis longus . This highlights the importance of the median nerve's role in thumb flexion.
  • ➤ supracondylar fracture
  • ➤ anterior interosseous nerve (branch of the median nerve)
  • ➤ flexor pollicis longus

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a dissection in the shoulder region and notes the structures passing through the clavipectoral fascia. Which of the following structures is known to pierce the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thoracoacromial Artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thoracoacromial artery is one of the key structures piercing the clavipectoral fascia, along with the cephalic vein, lateral pectoral nerve, and lymphatics. This anatomical relationship is essential for understanding the vascular and nervous supply in the shoulder region.
  • ➤ thoracoacromial artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.

options.label: B
options.text: There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side

options.label: C
options.text: The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

options.label: D
options.text: The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand is weak

questions.correct_answer: C. The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Froment’s sign is a clinical test for ulnar nerve dysfunction , specifically testing the function of the adductor pollicis . Weakness of the adductor pollicis results in compensatory flexion of the thumb, which is supplied by the median nerve .
  • ➤ Froment’s sign
  • ➤ ulnar nerve dysfunction
  • ➤ adductor pollicis
  • ➤ median nerve

questions.text: A 17-year-old, who was going to represent his college football team in an intercollege sports event, after one of his practice sessions felt a vague pain over the inner side of his midfoot just above the longitudinal arch. His orthopedician also noted redness, tenderness and swelling in the area pointed out by the patient. The below image is the X-ray of the patient’s foot. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the arrow pointed in the above image?

options.label: B
options.text: There is fracture of navicular bone

options.label: C
options.text: This bone is participating in lateral longitudinal arch

options.label: D
options.text: Supination & pronation occurs at this joint

questions.correct_answer: B. There is fracture of navicular bone
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) There is fracture of navicular bone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A navicular bone fracture is a common injury in athletes, especially due to repetitive stress or acute trauma. It plays a key role in the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and requires careful clinical and radiological assessment for diagnosis
  • ➤ navicular bone fracture
  • ➤ medial longitudinal arch

questions.text: A 22-year-old male athlete sustained an injury to his foot during one of his practice sessions. The given image is the x-ray of his foot. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: It is fracture of first metatarsal base

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base

options.label: C
options.text: The tuberosity of the pointed bone in the above image is least vascular

options.label: D
options.text: Its metadiaphyseal region receives the insertion of peroneus tertius tendon

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fifth metatarsal base is commonly fractured in athletic injuries, often caused by the pull of the peroneus brevis tendon. This type of fracture is important to differentiate from other midfoot injuries due to its implications for healing and treatment.
  • ➤ fifth metatarsal base
  • ➤ peroneus brevis

questions.text: An 18-year-old female while driving her two wheeler accidentally collided with a car from the opposite side on her way to college. She failed to balance her vehicle and eventually fell down while the vehicle dropped over her left lower leg. X-ray revealed fracture of lower fibula and cast was applied. Few days after this, she developed pain and numbness over most of the dorsum of her left foot and had difficulty in turning her sole outwards. Which could be the most probable sight of nerve compression in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral compartment of leg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superficial peroneal nerve , located in the lateral compartment of the leg , is responsible for eversion of the foot and sensory innervation of most of the dorsum of the foot. Fractures of the fibula may lead to nerve compression in this compartment, resulting in pain, sensory changes, and difficulty with eversion.
  • ➤ superficial peroneal nerve
  • ➤ lateral compartment of the leg

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a painful swelling in his right groin area. On physical examination, a bulge is noted at the mid inguinal point, which is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. This finding is most suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bulge at the mid-inguinal point is a hallmark of an indirect inguinal hernia , as this corresponds to the location of the deep inguinal ring , the entry point for this type of hernia.
  • ➤ mid-inguinal point
  • ➤ indirect inguinal hernia
  • ➤ deep inguinal ring

questions.text: A fourth-year medical student is revising the anatomy of the lower limb and focuses on the compartments of the thigh and their nerve supply. Which of the following correctly matches the three main compartments of the thigh with their respective innervating nerves?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Sciatic nerve; Posterior compartment: Obturator nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior compartment: Sciatic nerve; Medial compartment: Femoral nerve; Posterior compartment: Obturator nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Obturator nerve; Posterior compartment: Sciatic nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior compartment: Obturator nerve; Medial compartment: Sciatic nerve; Posterior compartment: Femoral nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Obturator nerve; Posterior compartment: Sciatic nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Obturator nerve; Posterior compartment: Sciatic nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nerve supply of the compartments of the thigh is as follows:
  • ➤ Anterior compartment : Femoral nerve . Medial compartment : Obturator nerve . Posterior compartment : Sciatic nerve .
  • ➤ Anterior compartment : Femoral nerve .
  • ➤ Anterior compartment
  • ➤ Femoral nerve
  • ➤ Medial compartment : Obturator nerve .
  • ➤ Medial compartment
  • ➤ Obturator nerve
  • ➤ Posterior compartment : Sciatic nerve .
  • ➤ Posterior compartment
  • ➤ Sciatic nerve

questions.text: During a practical session in anatomy, a group of medical students are asked to identify the nerve supply to the three compartments of the leg. Which of the following correctly associates each compartment of the leg with its respective innervating nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve; Lateral compartment: Deep peroneal nerve; Posterior compartment: Tibial nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior compartment: Deep peroneal nerve; Lateral compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve; Posterior compartment: Tibial nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior compartment: Tibial nerve; Lateral compartment: Deep peroneal nerve; Posterior compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve; Lateral compartment: Tibial nerve; Posterior compartment: Deep peroneal nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior compartment: Deep peroneal nerve; Lateral compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve; Posterior compartment: Tibial nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior compartment: Deep peroneal nerve; Lateral compartment: Superficial peroneal nerve; Posterior compartment: Tibial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nerve supply of the compartments of the leg is as follows:
  • ➤ Anterior compartment : Deep peroneal nerve . Lateral compartment : Superficial peroneal nerve . Posterior compartment : Tibial nerve .
  • ➤ Anterior compartment : Deep peroneal nerve .
  • ➤ Anterior compartment
  • ➤ Deep peroneal nerve
  • ➤ Lateral compartment : Superficial peroneal nerve .
  • ➤ Lateral compartment
  • ➤ Superficial peroneal nerve
  • ➤ Posterior compartment : Tibial nerve .
  • ➤ Posterior compartment
  • ➤ Tibial nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a complaint of unsteady gait. During examination, when asked to stand on her right leg, her left hip drops. This finding is not observed when she stands on her left leg. This clinical sign indicates weakness in which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right Gluteus Medius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness of the gluteus medius and minimus on the weight-bearing side (in this case, the right side ). These muscles are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve .
  • ➤ positive Trendelenburg sign
  • ➤ gluteus medius and minimus
  • ➤ right side
  • ➤ superior gluteal nerve

questions.text: A patient presented with painful vesicular eruptions as shown in image. Which division of trigeminal nerve is involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) V1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus involves the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve. Painful vesicular eruptions in the forehead and upper eyelid, particularly with Hutchinson’s sign, indicate V1 involvement.
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus
  • ➤ ophthalmic division (V1)

questions.text: Which chamber of the heart forms the base of the heart?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LA and RA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The base of the heart is primarily formed by the left atrium (LA) , with a minor contribution from the right atrium (RA) . It is located posteriorly, opposite the apex.
  • ➤ base of the heart
  • ➤ left atrium (LA)
  • ➤ right atrium (RA)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with recurrent episodes of palpitations and dizziness. An echocardiogram reveals an enlarged right atrium and evidence of a right-to-left shunt. During the cardiac catheterization procedure, the cardiologist observes a valve-like structure within the right atrium. Which of the following structures guards the opening of the coronary sinus and may be contributing to the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thebesian valve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Thebesian valve guards the opening of the coronary sinus in the right atrium, while the Eustachian valve guards the opening of the inferior vena cava . Abnormalities of the Thebesian valve can lead to impaired venous drainage and right atrial enlargement.
  • ➤ Thebesian valve
  • ➤ coronary sinus
  • ➤ Eustachian valve
  • ➤ inferior vena cava

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to persistent respiratory distress and feeding difficulties since birth. The baby appears to have labored breathing, and the parents report that he frequently vomits after feeds. On physical examination, the infant is tachypneic with retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray shows abdominal contents in the left thoracic cavity, confirming the diagnosis of a diaphragmatic hernia. Which of the following structure passes through the marked opening in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vagus nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The esophageal hiatus (T10 level) allows the passage of the esophagus , vagus nerve , and left gastric vessels . This region is often implicated in conditions such as diaphragmatic hernias and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) .
  • ➤ esophageal hiatus
  • ➤ esophagus
  • ➤ vagus nerve
  • ➤ left gastric vessels
  • ➤ diaphragmatic hernias
  • ➤ gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

questions.text: Portal vein is formed at which vertebral level
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) L2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The portal vein is formed at the L2 vertebral level by the union of the splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein behind the neck of the pancreas. This is a crucial anatomical landmark in abdominal circulation.
  • ➤ portal vein
  • ➤ L2 vertebral level
  • ➤ splenic vein
  • ➤ superior mesenteric vein

questions.text: Fascia related to penis, scrotum & perineum are

options.label: A
options.text: Buck’s fascia, dorto’s fascia, colle’s fascia

options.label: B
options.text: Dorto’s fascia, colle’s fascia, buck’s fascia

options.label: C
options.text: Buck’s fascia, colle’s fascia, dorto’s fascia

options.label: D
options.text: Colle’s fascia, dorto’s fascia, buck’s fascia

questions.correct_answer: A. Buck’s fascia, dorto’s fascia, colle’s fascia
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Buck’s fascia, dorto’s fascia, colle’s fascia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fasciae in the order from penis to scrotum to perineum are:
  • ➤ penis to scrotum to perineum
  • ➤ Buck’s fascia for the penis. Dartos fascia for the scrotum. Colle’s fascia for the perineum.
  • ➤ Buck’s fascia for the penis.
  • ➤ Buck’s fascia
  • ➤ Dartos fascia for the scrotum.
  • ➤ Dartos fascia
  • ➤ Colle’s fascia for the perineum.
  • ➤ Colle’s fascia

questions.text: Where in the body is the tissue shown in the image typically found?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Articular Cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tissue in the image is hyaline cartilage , commonly found in articular cartilage , growth plates, and the respiratory tract. It is characterized by chondrocytes in lacunae, a smooth extracellular matrix, and no visible fibers.
  • ➤ hyaline cartilage
  • ➤ articular cartilage

questions.text: Identify the histological slide given below
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This histological slide represents skin , identified by its keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and underlying connective tissue.
  • ➤ skin

questions.text: The reason for the long left recurrent laryngeal is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6th

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery , which forms the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum postnatally).
  • ➤ long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • ➤ 6th arch artery

questions.text: Which of the following is correct sequence of functional column of cranial nerve nuclei from medial to lateral side

options.label: A
options.text: GSE → BA → GVE → GVA → BE → GSA → SSA

options.label: B
options.text: GSE → BA → GVA → GVE → BE → GSA → SSA

options.label: C
options.text: GSE → BE → GVE → GSA → BE → GVA → SSA

options.label: D
options.text: GSE → BE → GVE → GVA → BA → GSA → SSA

questions.correct_answer: D. GSE → BE → GVE → GVA → BA → GSA → SSA
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GSE → BE→ GVE → GVA → BA → GSA → SSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cranial nerve nuclei follow a medial-to-lateral organization based on function: GSE → BE → GVE → GVA → BA → GSA → SSA . Motor nuclei are medial, while sensory nuclei are lateral.
  • ➤ GSE → BE → GVE → GVA → BA → GSA → SSA

questions.text: During embryonic development, the aortic arches play a crucial role in forming the major arteries of the head and neck region. The third aortic arch contributes to the formation of which important blood vessel?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Common carotid artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The third aortic arch forms:
  • ➤ third aortic arch
  • ➤ The common carotid artery (proximal part). The proximal internal carotid artery (distal part). It does not directly contribute to the external carotid or vertebral arteries.
  • ➤ The common carotid artery (proximal part).
  • ➤ common carotid artery
  • ➤ The proximal internal carotid artery (distal part). It does not directly contribute to the external carotid or vertebral arteries.
  • ➤ proximal internal carotid artery

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the urology clinic with complaints of painful urination and a sensation of burning at the tip of his penis for the past week. He mentions no history of similar symptoms in the past and denies any recent sexual activity. A physical examination reveals slight redness at the external urethral meatus. A urine sample is collected for analysis, and a swab is taken from the urethral tip for microscopic examination. Which type of epithelium is most likely to be found lining the tip of the urethra in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Non Keratinised stratified squamous epithelium
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non Keratinised stratified squamous epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The external urethral meatus is lined by non-keratinised stratified squamous epithelium , providing protection against mechanical friction and wet conditions.
  • ➤ external urethral meatus
  • ➤ non-keratinised stratified squamous epithelium

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a complaint of dragging his foot while walking. On examination, he demonstrates difficulty in dorsiflexing his foot at the ankle. This clinical presentation is most likely due to a lesion affecting which nerve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deep Peroneal (Fibular) Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foot drop , characterized by the inability to dorsiflex the foot, is due to dysfunction of the deep peroneal nerve , which innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg.
  • ➤ Foot drop
  • ➤ deep peroneal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct content of cavernous sinus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abducent nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The abducent nerve (CN VI) and internal carotid artery are the only direct contents of the cavernous sinus , while other cranial nerves lie in its lateral wall.
  • ➤ abducent nerve (CN VI)
  • ➤ internal carotid artery
  • ➤ cavernous sinus

questions.text: A patient complains of headache with periorbital pain, tearing/ lacrimation, drooling of saliva, jaw spasm/pain, with light and accommodation reflex normal and pupils neither dilated nor constricted. Features of the patient can be explained by the involvement of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigeminal neuralgia involves the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and can cause periorbital pain, lacrimation, tearing, and jaw spasm due to its extensive sensory and motor functions. The nerve originates from the ventral surface of the pons, as seen in the labeled image ( C ).
  • ➤ Trigeminal neuralgia
  • ➤ trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)
  • ➤ C

questions.text: The cell marked in the below slide is inhibitory to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells of the cerebellar cortex are inhibitory to the deep nuclei of the cerebellum , fine-tuning motor coordination and balance through GABAergic neurotransmission.
  • ➤ Purkinje cells
  • ➤ deep nuclei of the cerebellum
